abstract.p: California Health Services Department names the ad agency Ground Zero to handle its tobacco education account (S)

block.p: The California Health Services Department named Ground Zero in Marina del Rey, Calif., to handle its tobacco education account. Billings were estimated at $125 million for the five-year contract.

Colleen Stevens, chief for the media campaign at the Department of Health Services tobacco control program, said the decision came after a three-month review that was narrowed to Ground Zero and one other finalist, Dailey & Associates in West Hollywood, Calif., part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Other participants in the review included: DGWB in Irvine, Calif. and Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group.

Other participants in the review included: DGWB in Irvine, Calif. and Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group.

The incumbent was Asher/Gal & Partners in Los Angeles, which resigned in June, and in the meantime, has been named to handle the first large-scale anti-tobacco campaign for the state of Washington by the Washington Department of Health in Olympia, Wash.

Billings for the account, which will be handled in partnership with DeLaunay/Phillips in Seattle, were estimated at $15 million for a three-year contract. Asher/Gal changed its name from Asher & Partners after merging with Italia/Gal Advertising last month.
